qas.question: When did Russia's United Shipbuilding Corporation expect to begin design work for a new carrier?
What year was the goal for Russia's new carrier to achieve initial operational capability?
Where was the Northern Fleets nuclear-powered aircraft carrier supposed to be stationed?
Where was the Pacific Fleets nuclear-powered aircraft carrier supposed to be stationed?
When did Prussia's United Shipbuilding Corporation expect to begin design work for a new carrier?
What year was the goal for Russia's old carrier to achieve initial operational capability?
Where was the Southern Fleets nuclear-powered aircraft carrier supposed to be stationed?
Where was the Atlantic Fleets nuclear-powered aircraft carrier supposed to be stationed?

context: Speaking in St. Petersburg, Russia on 30 June 2011, the head of Russia's United Shipbuilding Corporation said his company expected to begin design work for a new carrier in <a0_0><b5_0>2016<b5_0/><a0_0/>, with a goal of beginning construction in 2018 and having the carrier achieve initial operational capability by <a1_0><b6_0>2023<b6_0/><a1_0/>. Several months later, on 3 November 2011 the <a2_0><b7_0>Russian newspaper<b7_0/><a2_0/> Izvestiya reported that the naval building plan now included (first) the construction of a new shipyard capable of building large hull ships, after which Moscow will build two (80,000 tons full load each) nuclear-powered aircraft carriers by 2027. The spokesperson said one carrier would be assigned to the Russian Navy's Northern Fleet at <a3_0><b8_0>Murmansk<b8_0/><a3_0/>, and the second would be stationed with the Pacific Fleet at <a4_0><b9_0>Vladivostok<b9_0/><a4_0/>.
